summary: A detailed victim claim form from a survivor of Jeffrey Epstein's sex trafficking operation, covering the period from late 2006 to May 2007 and beyond. The document describes systematic abuse, control, and the involvement of numerous associates, including Ghislaine Maxwell, Jean-Luc Brunel, and Alan Dershowitz. It also details ongoing psychological trauma, witness intimidation, and financial manipulation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The primary perpetrator who sexually abused, trafficked, and controlled the victim from late 2006 to May 2007, using threats, financial control, and an extensive network.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Described as Epstein's right-hand lady who controlled everything, including the victim. Met frequently from late 2006 to May 2007 and participated in the abuse.

persons.name: Jean Luc Brunel
persons.context: Met on Epstein's island and seen on multiple trips. Described as a top employee of Epstein's.

persons.name: Lesley Groff
persons.context: Epstein's assistant who monitored the victim's weight loss and communicated with her on Epstein's behalf. Described as a top lieutenant.

persons.name: Cathy Alexander
persons.context: Island manager on St. Little James with her husband Miles. Greeted the victim and was present during and after abuse, normalizing the situation.

persons.name: Miles Alexander
persons.context: Island manager on St. Little James with his wife Cathy. Present during the victim's trafficking and abuse.

persons.name: Igor Zinoviev
persons.context: Epstein's bodyguard who was present during the victim's trafficking and witnessed her distress, including an escape attempt.

persons.name: Alan Dershowitz
persons.context: Epstein's lawyer friend whom the victim was forced to perform sexual acts with in early 2007. Met on three occasions.

persons.name: Sergey Brin
persons.context: Met on Epstein's island on 01/01/2007 with Ann Wojcicki. Witnessed the victim's traumatized state but did nothing.

persons.name: Ann Wojcicki
persons.context: Met on Epstein's island on 01/01/2007 with Sergey Brin. Witnessed the victim's traumatized state but did nothing.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Mentioned as the victim's attorney who confirmed Igor Zinoviev's witness statement in his book 'Relentless Pursuit'.

persons.name: Alex Acosta
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to Epstein's plea deal, which triggered the victim.

connections.description: Maxwell is described as Epstein's right-hand lady who controlled everything, including the victim. They worked together to abuse and control victims.
Brunel is described as a top employee of Epstein's, present on the island and involved in the operation.
Groff was Epstein's assistant who monitored the victim's weight and communicated on his behalf.
Dershowitz is described as Epstein's lawyer friend. The victim was forced to perform sexual acts with him.
Cathy and her husband Miles were island managers paid to observe and ensure smooth operations, normalizing the abuse.
Miles and his wife Cathy were island managers paid to observe and ensure smooth operations, normalizing the abuse.
Igor was Epstein's bodyguard whose job was to observe everything, including the victim's distress and escape attempts.
Visited Epstein's island together on 01/01/2007 and witnessed the victim's traumatized state.

events.title: First visit to Epstein's island and start of abuse
events.description: The victim was coerced to visit Epstein's island, St. Little James, where Epstein's sexual abuse started and continued until May 2007. Her passport was taken, and she was trapped.

events.title: Flight to St. Little James with associate
events.description: The victim flew on Epstein's plane to the island with an employee and best friend of her recruiter.

events.title: New Year's Day visit by Sergey Brin and Ann Wojcicki
events.description: Sergey Brin and Ann Wojcicki visited Epstein's island, witnessed the victim's traumatized state, but did nothing.

events.title: Weight monitoring and coercion
events.description: Epstein's assistant Lesley Groff monitored the victim's weight loss, requiring nude pictures, as a condition for Epstein's false promise of educational support.

events.title: Sexual assault by Alan Dershowitz
events.description: The victim was forced by Epstein to perform sexual acts with his lawyer friend, Alan Dershowitz, and another associate at Epstein's mansion.

events.title: Escape from Epstein
events.description: The victim managed to 'escape' from Epstein's control after months of daily abuse.

events.title: Epstein's jail sentence begins
events.description: Epstein's jail sentence started, noted by the victim's then-partner who sent her an article link saying 'Finally'.

events.title: End of relationship with enabler partner
events.description: The victim's partner, described as an enabler, orchestrated a final exit by clearing out her house and leaving, marking the end of his 'job'.

events.title: Victim comes forward and is followed
events.description: After coming forward in 2016, the victim was located and followed, forcing her into hiding for two years.

locations: 9 East 71st Street, New York (Epstein's New York Mansion)
St. Little James, US Virgin Islands (Epstein's private island)
New York apartment (location near victim's old room share)
keyFacts: The victim was trafficked and sexually abused by Jeffrey Epstein from late September/October 2006 to May 2007, with daily rapes sometimes occurring up to three times a day.
Ghislaine Maxwell is described as Epstein's right-hand lady who controlled everything, including the victim, and without whom 'there would be no Epstein'.
The victim was forced to perform sexual acts with Epstein's lawyer friend, Alan Dershowitz, in early 2007 at Epstein's mansion.
Epstein used an extensive network of enablers including island managers (Cathy & Miles Alexander), bodyguards (Igor Zinoviev), and assistants (Lesley Groff) to control and monitor victims.

The victim describes being manipulated and controlled by a subsequent partner (name redacted) who acted as an enabler to silence her, including arranging therapy to prevent her from going to authorities.
